Teaching and educational activities for the first cycle of education and for the educational services for children continues to take place in presence.    Per le istituzioni scolastiche secondarie di secondo grado viene incrementato il ricorso alla didattica digitale integrata for a percentage equal to at least 75% of the activities, organising the entry and exit times of pupils, through the possible use of afternoon shifts and possibly postponing entry into schools to  9.00 a.m.    Field trips, exchange programs, guided tours and educational outings are suspended. On the other hand, activities related to cross skills, orientation and internship activities are allowed whenever it is possible to ensure compliance with the current health and safety regulations.    According to the evolution of the epidemiological framework, universities will have to set up plans to organise in-presence and distance learning, according to the different educational needs.  For secondary schools, the use of integrated digital learning will be increased by 75%.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201028122734/http://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioFaqNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=english&id=230  Red zones require schools to close for a month  https://web.archive.org/web/20201105051358/https://newseu.cgtn.com/news/2020-03-10/Italy-s-COVID-19-red-zones-What-are-the-restrictions--OJ9k8w5Klq/index.html

It is mandatory to carry a face mask with you at all times. These must be worn, not only in closed spaces accessible to the public, as in the past, but also in indoor spaces in general, other than private homes, and also in all outdoor spaces. Exceptions are made in cases where, due to the characteristics of the place or the actual circumstances, the condition of isolation from non-residents is continuously guaranteed. Children under six years of age, people with pathologies or disabilities incompatible with the use of a face mask and those who interact with the latter, are excluded from the obligation to wear a face mask. Furthermore, the use of a face will not be mandatory during any sports activity.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201028122734mp_/http://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioFaqNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=english&id=230#6

The government continued to enforce a policy that requires most schools to adopt online teaching while gives certain schools the option to open on-site classes.     “The Ministry of Education and Science of Kazakhstan introduced optional on-site classes for primary schools, trying to balance the pandemic risks and educational needs of younger children. Over 2,800 rural schools in remote areas of Kazakhstan continue to operate in strict compliance with the new sanitary and hygiene norms. They provide multi-shift schooling for pupils, whose parents opted in for offline studies.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027082249/https://www.unicef.org/eca/stories/education-rural-kazakhstan-during-pandemic

The government announced new policies to give schools and parents the option to return to on-site classes, with strict compliance with sanitation requirements. However, these are only options that are permitted, and other schools continue to conduct online teaching.     Note: it is not clear when the second quarter will begin, and this policy might not have gone into effect yet. But this will not change the coded ordinal value.    "From the second quarter to transfer to the traditional format the work of urban and rural schools up to 300 students."    "At the request of the parents, allow training in the duty classes from 1 to 5 grades, in international schools - up to the 7th grade."    "At the same time, it is imperative to observe the sanitary and disinfection regime, mask regime, chess seating and social distance."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027085815/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/kak-budut-uchit-sya-shkol-niki-vo-2-chetverti-reshenie-mvk_a3711015    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027085445/https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/edu/press/news/details/113948?lang=kk
On October 26, the Ministry of Education allowed school learners from 1 to 5 grades to attend schools.   Link: https://archive.vn/qQcrt
Primary school grades are allowed to attend schools whereas high school/ universities are still closed.  Link: https://archive.vn/vynqY
High schools and universities are still closed. The government is not planning to fully open schools in green zone regions.  Link: https://archive.vn/TOsMA

The government continues to enforce a policy that allows some businesses to open on condition that sanitary and other restrictive measures are in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027090846/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/kinoteatram-v-almaty-razreshili-rabotat_a3710926    https://archive.fo/nk0y0    https://archive.fo/X8S1D

From November 2, theaters are allowed to operate with occupancy of no more than 30%, but no more than 100 people in the hall. Whereas cinemas are still closed across the country.  Link: https://archive.vn/RgEbv

Quarantine Measures: By and large, countrywide quarantine restrictions have been relaxed.  Businesses that were previously closed – including gyms and fitness centers, pools, beaches, cultural facilities, museums, exhibits, entertainment centers, religious facilities, some movie theaters, food courts, and recreational facilities – have reopened, at least on weekdays, and may be subject to capacity limitations.  However, amid concerns of a possible fall/winter uptick, some regional and local governments are imposing restrictions once again.   Link: https://archive.vn/s9ThM

The government continues to enforce a policy that prohibits public events. Recent news coverage indicates the police has carried out operations to ensure this policy is observed.     "All large events and family gatherings are prohibited. Individual and group outdoor fitness activities are permitted, and people may walk in parks and other public spaces in groups of three or less."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027092123/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/obschestvennyy-kontrol-semeynye-posidelki-i-svad-by-provodilis-v-kyzylorde_a3707769    https://archive.fo/59GzJ
From November 2, the government allowed citizens to attend religious gatherings - up to 100 people in one room. However, Friday prayers at the mosque are prohibited.  Link: https://archive.vn/Gxi0d
From November 9, the Pavlodar region prohibits religious gatherings.  Link: https://archive.vn/ktjb2
All large events and family gatherings are prohibited.  Link: https://archive.vn/utWXb
All large events and family gatherings are prohibited. Link: https://archive.vn/s9ThM

The government continues to enforce a policy that restricts gatherings to three people or less.    “All large events and family gatherings are prohibited. Individual and group outdoor fitness activities are permitted, and people may walk in parks and other public spaces in groups of three or less. ”    https://archive.fo/59GzJ
On October 28, the Almaty city administration declared new measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Accordingly, private gatherings are allowed for up to 3 people.   Link: https://archive.vn/v5Lc0
Shymkent city and the Kostanay region announced a quarantine from November 6 until November 23. Accordingly, no gatherings in public of more than 3 people.  Link: https://archive.vn/UBtKe

According to the local government decrees, no more than 3 people are allowed to walk in parks and other public spaces in Shymkent, East Kazakhstan, and the Akmola region. However, the US Embassy website states that "individual and group outdoor fitness activities are permitted, and people may walk in parks and other public spaces in groups of three or less" which relates to the nationwide policy. As a citizen of Kazakhstan, I would say that there are no strict measures on gatherings across the country. Only some regions are implementing the restrictions. It should be noted that Shymkent city residents are not fully complying with the "no more than 3 people" rule.  Links: https://archive.vn/JQyYt https://archive.vn/utWXb
From November 20, Almaty region administration does not allow more than 3 people in a group to walk outdoors.  Link: https://archive.vn/HJnYo

From October 28, Almaty city administration has restricted public transport operations by reducing working hours during weekdays. From November 9, Shymkent, the Kostanay region, and the North Kazakhstan region will restrict the public transport operations by closing on weekends and reducing working hours during weekdays. Whereas the Akmola region is restricting public transport operations from November 7.  Links: https://archive.vn/JQm5Q https://archive.vn/UBtKe
From November 7, the Akmola region is restricting public transport operations.  Links: https://archive.vn/UBtKe
Public transport operations are restricted in the Akmola region, West Kazakhstan region, and Shymkent city.   Link: https://archive.vn/JQyYt
Public transport operations are banned during weekends in the Kostanay region.  Link: https://archive.vn/jogfK

By and large, the countrywide restrictions have been loosened. In certain regions, however, quarantine measures are strengthened and extended. There are no curfew hours announced across the country. However, some regions and cities announced a quarantine by reducing business operation hours and recommending elderly people to stay at home.   Link: https://archive.vn/Qzju5 https://archive.vn/UBtKe

"    https://archive.fo/59GzJ    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027101525/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/izbegat-poezdok-v-obschestvennom-transporte-i-vyletov-v-zarubezhnye-strany-poprosili-almatincev_a3708386

Also, Pavlodar city will set up checkpoints from November 9. People are required to register at pvlinfo.kz to cross the checkpoints.  Link: https://archive.vn/UBtKe
From November 9, Shymkent city administration prohibited inter-regional and inter-city movement.  Link: https://archive.vn/wJHEl
East Kazakhstan continues to keep about 15 sanitary checkpoints to control exit and entry from/to the region.   Link: https://archive.vn/pdsvn

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes, in some cases*  Kazakhstan’s regions are empowered to take additional measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 as necessary, including erecting checkpoints to limit travel in and out of cities and oblasts.  Before pursuing domestic travel in Kazakhstan, we urge you to research whether checkpoints might be in a place that could restrict your ability to travel.   For regional information please see the websites listed in the Local Resources section at the bottom of this message. From 26 October 2020, all foreigners arriving in Kazakhstan through international flights must have a certificate of PCR tests for COVID-19.     "Amendments were made to the resolution of the Chief Sanitary Doctor of the Republic of Kazakhstan, according to which, in the absence of a PCR certificate for COVID-19, passengers are not allowed to board an aircraft on international flights."    It should be noted that a restrictive measure with effects equivalent to this policy seemed to have been already enforced.    "A British citizen was deported on October 24 this year. from Aktau airport due to the lack of a PCR certificate. "    "Effective October 6, 2020, the Government of Kazakhstan is requiring foreign travelers arriving in Kazakhstan to provide a negative COVID-19 PCR test dated no more than three days prior to their entry to Kazakhstan.  If they are unable to provide negative PCR test results, they will be denied entry.  In addition, each traveler must undergo a temperature check and fill out a questionnaire on prior travel, potential COVID-19 exposure, and contact "    https://archive.fo/59GzJ    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027103200/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/priletevshego-bez-pcr-spravki-britanca-deportirovali-iz-kazahstana_a3710343    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027103234/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/zapret-aviakompaniyam-na-posadku-passazhirov-bez-pcr-spravok-kasaetsya-lish-inostrancev-pravitel-stvo-rk_a3711410

Link: https://archive.vn/wNeAx

Lithuania’s government on Wednesday declared a three-week lockdown starting on Nov.7, to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus which has accelerated in recent weeks in the Baltic nation.  Secondary schools and universities will be closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201114114424/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-lithuania/update-1-lithuania-to-enter-three-week-covid-lockdown-on-saturday-idINL8N2HQ525

Lithuania’s government on Wednesday declared a three-week lockdown starting on Nov.7, to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus which has accelerated in recent weeks in the Baltic nation.  Gyms will be closed, shops will limit number of customers and restaurants will only be able to serve take-aways.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201114114424/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-lithuania/update-1-lithuania-to-enter-three-week-covid-lockdown-on-saturday-idINL8N2HQ525

source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201101210959/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-28-october-2020  From 30 October to 13 November 2020, there shall be no events and gatherings held indoor and outdoor in public places, except: high-performance sporting and cultural events (with several crowd restrictions described below); funerals.    crowd restrictions:  * they are held indoors with maximum 300 spectators;    * spectators watch an event seated at a 2 m distance from each other except for family members;   * spectators wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth (face masks, respirators or other equipment) during the entire event (the requirement to wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth (face masks, respirators or other equipment) will not be applicable to persons with disability who cannot wear a mask or where wearing it may adversely affect their health condition; they are recommended to wear a face shield instead);    * electronic distribution of tickets and/or registration of spectators and/or participants, as well as control of the access of spectators and/or participants to the venue is ensured;   * they are held outdoors with maximum 400 spectators provided the conditions referred to above are met:;   events are organised and held where the organisers of an event can ensure electronic distribution of tickets and/or registration of spectators and/or participants and control the access of spectators and/or participants to the venue of the event;
https://web.archive.org/web/20201114114424/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-lithuania/update-1-lithuania-to-enter-three-week-covid-lockdown-on-saturday-idINL8N2HQ525

A continuation of the restrictions on the size of gatherings continues in Lithuania esp. given the targeted quarantines in select districts across the country. source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201101210959/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-28-october-2020    Examples of such restrictions include: "In public places, groups of no more than 5 people (with 2 metres distance between the groups). In Raseiniai district - groups of no more than 2 people (with 2 metres distance between the groups)."

Lithuania’s government on Wednesday declared a three-week lockdown starting on Nov.7, to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus which has accelerated in recent weeks in the Baltic nation.  Public groups of more than 5 people will be banned and no more than 10 people will be allowed at marriages or funerals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201114114424/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-lithuania/update-1-lithuania-to-enter-three-week-covid-lockdown-on-saturday-idINL8N2HQ525

19th October 2020, Self-isolation for 14 days is mandatory upon your arrival from COVID-19 affected countries. Self-isolation could last for 10 days, if a person gets a negative COVID-19 test result after at least 8 days in isolation. It also applies, when COVID-19 affected countries are crossed (by car, public transport, etc.), except air transport, if you do not leave transit area at the airport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201023071734/https://www.govilnius.lt/media-news/important-information-regarding-the-coronavirus

14-day quarantine policy when entering the country continues in Lithuania. This policy was updated on Oct 28 2020.    source:https://web.archive.org/web/20201023071734/https://www.govilnius.lt/media-news/important-information-regarding-the-coronavirus

28th October 2020, Self-isolation for 10 days is mandatory upon your arrival from COVID-19 affected countries. Self-isolation "will not be required where there is a negative result of a test for COVID-19 (coronavirus infection) taken at maximum 48 hours before the entry to the Republic of Lithuania."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201101231848/https://www.govilnius.lt/media-news/important-information-regarding-the-coronavirus

Citizens of Estonia, Cyprus, Germany, Italy, Sweden as well as those of Denmark’s Hovedstaden and Nordjylland regions wishing to enter Lithuania from today, November 2, must first comply with the requirement of self-quarantine and testing procedures, as these countries have been placed on Lithuania’s COVID-19 red list, the country’s Ministry of Health has announced.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104191902/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/lithuania-expands-its-list-of-high-risk-eu-countries-obliges-more-arrivals-to-self-isolate/

Face masks are mandatory in all indoor public places, including shops, points of service and on public transport. Face masks are also mandatory in all indoor and outdoor events as well as in public catering establishments (restaurants, cafes, bars and other catering establishments). However, visitors to public catering establishments will be able to remove their protective equipment (masks, respirators, shields, etc.) while sitting at a table or bar.    Exceptions:  - Where service cannot be provided to a customer wearing a mask (e.g., beard trimming), the customer will be able to stay without a mask during the provision of the service.  - While exercising in sports clubs and staying in amusement parks (e.g. swimming pools).  - People with disabilities who are unable to wear face and mouth protection due to their disability are exempt. For example, those with respiratory disorders, mental disorders, autism spectrum disorders and others. In cases where a person with a disability (such as movement) can still wear face protection, they should.  - For children under 6 years    https://web.archive.org/web/20201023071734/https://www.govilnius.lt/media-news/important-information-regarding-the-coronavirus

sources:   - https://web.archive.org/web/20201101210959/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-28-october-2020  - https://web.archive.org/web/20201101234607/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/local-quarantines-are-declared-in-individual-municipalities  - https://web.archive.org/web/20201101234723/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/another-eight-municipalities-put-under-quarantine    Protective face masks are required in general across Lithuania: in public transport; at points of sale or service  Specifically in quarantined districts: Face masks are mandatory in all public spaces with certain exceptions:  * when exercising;   * professionals of high-performance sports and physical activity participating in high-performance sports training and competitions, high-performance sports and physical activity instructors and referees;    performers during events;   * in catering facilities when sitting at the table or bar, also during the provision of a service where a service cannot be provided in a mask;   * persons with disability who cannot wear a mask due to their health condition or where it can adversely affect their health condition;   * when outside populated areas (cities, towns, villages, single-homestead settlements and dacha (garden) settlements) and when there are no other people within the radius of 20 metres, except for family members.
https://web.archive.org/web/20201114114424/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-lithuania/update-1-lithuania-to-enter-three-week-covid-lockdown-on-saturday-idINL8N2HQ525

An accelerated dispatch of COVID-19 test prescriptions and mobile testing teams to schools were set up for improved responsiveness. For instance, when only one pupil or teacher in a class is tested positive for COVID-19, the class concerned continues to attend school, while being separated from other classes within the school building. The pupils and the teacher(s) of the class are invited to be tested on the 6th day after the last contact with the person tested positive. ?    https://web.archive.org/web/20201117070847/https://covid19.public.lu/en/news-covid19/communiques/2020/11/06-testing-schools.html

As of Nov.5, not able to find exact historical policy for the period of Oct. 20 to Oct. 29. But based on the RTL news (source below): private gathering limit was reduced from 10 to 4 people from Oct. 30, which implies 10 people was the limit before Oct. 30, and that aligns with the policy recorded before Oct. 20. So record this indicator as 2 "require cancelling", following coding interpretation guideline (Nov.4 version) "When private gatherings of only 10 or less are permitted (e.g. C4=4), this restriction would prevent public events from taking place, so they are recorded as required to cancel."  Sources:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201106013947/https://today.rtl.lu/news/luxembourg/a/1604513.html

No policy change. According to official government website (lasted updated on Nov. 4): “The person who tested positive is asked to provide the Health Inspectorate with the contact details of all close contacts they have had in the days prior to the test or before the onset of symptoms. Afterwards, the identified people are informed that they have been in contact with a sick person (the identity of the sick person is only revealed if he or she agrees). The Health Inspectorate officers then inquire about the state of health of the contact and inform him/her about the necessary measures and precautions, including protective measures. Based on the information obtained it is decided whether and when a COVID-19 test should be carried out.”   Source:   http://web.archive.org/web/20201106065603/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/contact-transmission.html

In view of the epidemiological assessments of the growing risks of spread of the COVID-19 virus, a national state of emergency will be declared in Latvia, to be in effect between 9 November and 6 December.    The teaching for Year 1—6 pupils will be in person. Preschool and special education facilities, child day-care facilities will remain open. Year 7—12 pupils, university students, and those engaged in professional training and adult education will study remotely (except for practical classes). Children’s camps, interest-based education, professional education programmes and amateur artist and other creative group rehearsals will be discontinued (except for private sessions and if the people involved are from the same household).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113081120/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/state-emergency-be-declared-latvia-9-november

From 26 October to 15 November, work is suspended (places do not provide services) related to indoor entertainment for children (entertainment and amusement centers, children's playrooms, trampoline parks and babysitting rooms, including shopping centers);    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026220648/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/nosaka-stingrakus-pulcesanas-un-citus-drosibas-pasakumus
No change in previous policy

In view of the epidemiological assessments of the growing risks of spread of the COVID-19 virus, a national state of emergency will be declared in Latvia, to be in effect between 9 November and 6 December.  Latvia’s residents will have access to those in-person services that have are particularly important for a healthy and safe day-to-day life, and whose availability cannot be postponed.    ACCORDING TO ABOVE NOTE, 3G IS THE APPROPIATE LEVEL. HOWEVER, COMPARED TO OTHER COUNTRIES, MORE THAN JUST THE "ESSENTIAL" BUSINESSES REMAIN OPEN WHICH IS WHY LEVEL 2G MIGHT BE SUITABLE, TOO.    No entertainment events, such as discotheques, may take place. Gambling venues and bars, skating rinks, children’s party venues, entertainment and amusement centres, trampoline parks, playgrounds and child day-care rooms (including those in shopping centres) will be closed. Water entertainment and amusement centres, saunas and spa facilities will be closed. Public natural paths will be available for individual visits; museums, exhibitions, libraries and other cultural venues will remain open. No events will take place at these venues.  Food service venues may only serve food as take-out, except for those in educational institutions, at workplaces and at the Riga airport.  On weekends and official holidays, only grocery stores, pharmacies, veterinary pharmacies, animal feed shops, book shops, newspaper and magazine shops, optician’s, hygiene and household product stores, telecommunication service and product providers.    In shopping venues, there must be 10 square metres of space per visitor, and visitors must wear masks. Masks must also be worn in outdoor markets and in other outdoor shopping areas.    Shopping centres are defined as buildings equipped for providing continuous and regular retail services, with a total retail space of at least 10,000 square metres, or with a total of at least 10 retail workers or service providers employed in its individual retail outlets.    The working hours for cultural venues (which may only be attended on an individual basis), exhibitions, churches and other religious facilities will be reduced to 6:00–20:00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113081120/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/state-emergency-be-declared-latvia-9-november

No change to previous policy (running until 6th December by latest legislation).    Bear in mind, however, the following note:  ACCORDING TO ABOVE NOTE, 3G IS THE APPROPIATE LEVEL. HOWEVER, COMPARED TO OTHER COUNTRIES, MORE THAN JUST THE "ESSENTIAL" BUSINESSES REMAIN OPEN WHICH IS WHY LEVEL 2G MIGHT BE SUITABLE, TOO.    [...] Catering facilities such as cafes, restaurants and bars will have strict requirements during an emergency. Meals may only be served for take-away. The exceptions are catering services at educational establishments and at the airport, as well as on-site catering at a place of work, such as a factory, with a strict organization of the flow of people.[...] Working time restrictions are set for cultural sites, such as museums, exhibitions and places of religious activity - they will be open no earlier than 6.00 and end no later than 20.00. Sports clubs will be allowed to work until 22.00 to prevent crowding of people who go to the gym individually. [...] On weekends and public holidays, only grocery stores, pharmacies (including veterinary), optical stores, pet stores, bookstores, press outlets, hygiene and household goods stores, as well as telecommunications goods and services will be allowed to operate in shopping centers. Such restrictions are necessary to prevent people from unnecessarily gathering in shopping malls for leisure purposes. [...] At the same time, street sales and outdoor sales in the market area will be allowed, but everyone will have to wear face masks here. At any point of sale, 10 m2 per visitor must be provided to avoid congestion.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201118085042/https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/preses_relizes/6489_vm_sobrid_jaatjauno_prasmes_sadzivot_ar_covid19_ta_lai_varet

No evident policy change.    - Indoor events for up to 300 persons and outdoor events for up to 1,000 persons may be organised, subject to physical distancing, safety measures, and the rules set by the organiser   - A distance of at least one metre or a protective barrier between each group of fixed, personalised seats must be observed at events, following the rule that two visitors may be seated next to each other even if they are not from the same household; up to four visitors may be seated next to each other if they come from one household.   - When leaving the seat, visitors should keep a two-metre distance from each other if they are not from the same household.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Twenty-one municipalities, including the cities of Vilnius, Kaunas and Klaipeda, have been previously red-zoned and quarantined.   – Facemasks are mandatory in all public places.  – One-metre space must be observed in inter-city public transport.  – Groups of more than five people are not allowed, except members of the same household.  – Two-metre distances must be maintained between groups in events and public places.  – Public-sector institutions are switching fully or partially to remote work.  – Retail businesses must manage client flows, ensuring a space of at least 10 square metres per customer.  – Hospital visits are suspended, except in cases where patients are terminally ill, under 14 years old, or women in maternity wards.  – Religious communities are advised to suspend services or avoid crowding.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104191028/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1267705/lithuania-adds-13-municipalities-to-coronavirus-red-zone
No change in previous policy

In view of the epidemiological assessments of the growing risks of spread of the COVID-19 virus, a national state of emergency will be declared in Latvia, to be in effect between 9 November and 6 December.    All in-person public events (such as theatre and music performances) are cancelled and banned. No more than 10 people, and members of no more than two households may participate in private meetings. No more than 50 people may participate in public gatherings, rallies and political demonstrations. Members of more than two households may attend to a funeral, up to a total of 10 people (not including the individuals conducting the funerary proceedings).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113081120/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/state-emergency-be-declared-latvia-9-november
No change to previous policy (running until 6th December by latest legislation).

From 24 October, private event venues may have a maximum of 10 people indoors and 100 people outdoors . If a private event is held in a public place, such as a restaurant, rented sauna, club, etc., then guests must be provided with fixed, personalized seating, 2 meters distance (except for persons from one household), as well as the event can take place until 24.00;    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026220648/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/nosaka-stingrakus-pulcesanas-un-citus-drosibas-pasakumus

In view of the epidemiological assessments of the growing risks of spread of the COVID-19 virus, a national state of emergency will be declared in Latvia, to be in effect between 9 November and 6 December.    In private events, no more than 10 people at a time are allowed to gather and from no more than two households, except for a funeral. No more than 10 people are allowed to gather at a funeral at the same time (excluding persons directly involved in the provision of the funeral), but they may come from more than two households.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113082125/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/ob-obyavlenii-rezhima-chrezvychaynoy-situacii

Using public transport:  - Face masks must be worn  - Hygiene measures must be observed  - Instructions available on public transport must be observed  - Upon arrival in Latvia from countries where the number of Covid-19 cases per 100,000 inhabitants exceeds 82,7 (list of countries is available on the SPKC website), public transport may only be used in order to get to the place of self-isolation, and a mouth and nose covering must be used  - Foreigners travelling to their home country must use a mouth and nose covering, if the required period of self-isolation since their arrival in Latvia has not yet finished  - Public transport must not be used by passengers who have tested positive for Covid-19 and by persons who have been in contact with a person infected with Covid-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

- The need for travel must be carefully assessed  - Self-isolation is not required after arriving from countries where the number of new Covid-19 infections does not exceed 61,9 new cases per 100000 inhabitants over the course of the last two weeks  - 10-day self-isolation must be observed after arriving in Latvia from countries with more than 61,9 new cases of Covid-19 infection per 100000 inhabitants over the course of the last two weeks  - 10-day self-isolation must be observed after arriving in Latvia from a country to which international passenger transport services are not being carried out    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures    https://web.archive.org/web/20201023061901/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/valstu-saslimstibas-raditaji-ar-covid-19-0

When arriving in Latvia by passenger carrier transport, a form must be completed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113091405/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/careful-travel/persons-who-wish-arrive-latvia

No change to previous entry:    "Currently, the actions that people are required to take after returning from abroad depend on the morbidity rates in the country where they have been: if in the last 14 days one has been in an EU, EEA, or a separate country with a 14-day cumulative number of Covid-19 cases that exceeds 50 people per 100,000 inhabitants (see list here) or if one has spent time in a third country, one must observe self-isolation. If one is returning to Latvia from the EU, EEA, or a separate country where the above-mentioned indicator does not exceed 50 people, one is not required to observe self-isolation. However, if one transits through any “unsafe countries” on the route back from a “safe” country, then self-isolation must be observed; in order to avoid the need to observe self-isolation, one must choose a safer return route"    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113091405/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/careful-travel/persons-who-wish-arrive-latvia  https://web.archive.org/save/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/en/support-society/careful-travel/after-arrival-latvia

No change in previous policy

Given the awareness of the effect that the state-of-emergency measures can have on the economy and the general public, a support mechanism is being developed to support employers, employees and those parts of the public most likely to be affected by the measures introduced to limit the spread of the virus.    Measures will be implemented on November 12th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113081120/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/state-emergency-be-declared-latvia-9-november

While Covid-19 restrictions continue, the government has decided on support measures to companies suffering from Covid-19. The government has approved the following support measures:    "Self-employed persons who apply the general tax payment regime, persons who receive royalties, who have not registered as performers of economic activities, and sole proprietorships whose economic activity has been suspended as a result of the restrictions, or whose income from economic activity has decreased by at least 20% in comparison to this year’s August, September and October, will be eligible for support in the amount of 75% of the average income from economic activity or royalties during Q3 this year; but not exceeding EUR 1,000."    "Self-employed persons who pay the micro-enterprise tax will be eligible for 50% of monthly average income for Q3 this year. Payers of patent payments will be eligible for support of EUR 330."    "Employees working at companies affected by Covid-19 will be eligible for idle-time payment. This support will be at least EUR 330, but not more than EUR 1,000 a month. In addition to idle-time payment, the employee can receive an extra EUR 50 for each dependent child under 24."    "The regulations state that support as compensation for idle time will be paid to the employee at the amount of 70% of the reported monthly average gross salary from 1 August to 30 October this year or of the reported monthly average gross salary for those months after 1 August when the employee actually worked. An employee of a micro-enterprise taxpayer will be eligible for idle-time payment of 50% of the monthly average gross salary at the micro-enterprise for Q3 2020."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201118091001/https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=293a20d7-ee9e-4c68-8962-4dca8247c181

Addition to the support scheme running from 12th November:    "To help companies whose employees are sick or where the entire staff is forced to stay in quarantine due to illness caused by Covid-19, during the Covid-19 crisis the state will pay the first three days of sick-leave for employees suffering from a respiratory disease and staying in quarantine."    "From 16 November this year until 30 June 2021, a person who has received a “B” sick-leave certificate due to Covid-19 or staying in quarantine will receive sickness benefit during this period from the first day of incapacity for work. These rules likewise apply to persons whose sick-leave certificate has been issued due to respiratory disease. On the other hand, if a person receives an “A” sick-leave certificate, the employer will pay sickness benefit for the term until the 10th day of temporary incapacity for work." No evident policy change.    Everyone has the opportunity to take the state-paid Covid-19 test even if there are no symptoms.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200929091233/https://covid19.gov.lv/biezak-uzdotie-jautajumi (archived 29 Sept 2020)    Any Latvian citizen with a suspicion of infection (visiting other countries, contact with persons who have been abroad, staying in public places where it was not possible to observe physical distance, frequent use of public transport, etc. conditions of increased risk of infection during the last 14 days) can initiate to carry out laboratory examinations paid for from the state budget on Covid-19 by applying for a laboratory examination by telephone (telephone 8303).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201014175129/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/valsts-apmaksatas-covid-19-analizes-kam-tas-veic-un-ka-jarikojas (archived 14 Oct 2020)

How can COVID-19 be analyzed?  From October 26, there is a new testing procedure. If Covid-19 is suspected, you should first contact your doctor. If the healthcare professional, after hearing the patient about their symptoms, decides that a test is needed, an e-mail will be issued. Then, when the person calls 8303, he or she will be queued for the test as soon as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026224302/https://covid19.gov.lv/biezak-uzdotie-jautajumi

20.10.2020  Ministry of Health  Ministry of Health: priority should be given to medical or hygienic face mask  In order to make the mandatory use of face masks clearer, the government today, 20 October, clarified the text of the rules and the accompanying explanation (annotation of amendments to the rules).  At present, it is mandatory to wear face masks:    public transport;  in taxis for passengers and the driver, unless another special barrier has been established, such as a wall;  bus stations, railway stations, ports and airports;  shop, pharmacy, postage, gas stations and other indoor outlets;  museum, library, exhibition halls, concert halls, cinemas and similar venues, in the absence of an event with personalised seating;  in churches in the absence of an event with personalised seats;  hospitals;  when providing an indoor service where a distance of 2 metres cannot be respected, there are no physically separating barriers and staying for more than 15 minutes.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/veselibas-ministrija-aicina-iespeju-robezas-stradajiet-attalinati

- From 24 October mouth and nose covering should be worn in any public place.  - Mouth and nose covering should be used during indoor cultural events. The covering can not be removed if you are sitting in a fixed, personalized seat at a cultural event.   - A homemade mask should be made of at least three layers of suitable material (cotton, nylon, etc.) and have ties to secure it behind the ears or behind the head  - May not be used for children under 13 years of age and people who cannot use it for medical reasons, such as functional impairment    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Face masks must be worn:    On public transport;  In taxis by passengers and by the driver, if a special barrier, such as a separating wall, is not installed;  At bus stations, railway stations, ports, and airports;  In a shop, pharmacy, post office, gas station, and other indoor points of sale;  In markets and outdoor street shopping venues;  In a museum, library, exhibition hall, and in other cultural venues;  In churches;  In any other public place;  Providing and receiving services;  In medical institutions;  In the common areas of educational institutions (both children aged 13 and over and teachers).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113094112/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers

Face masks must be worn:    "On public transport;  In taxis by passengers and by the driver, if a special barrier, such as a separating wall, is not installed;  At bus stations, railway stations, ports, and airports;  In a shop, pharmacy, post office, gas station, and other indoor points of sale;  In markets and outdoor street shopping venues;  In a museum, library, exhibition hall, and in other cultural venues;  In churches;  In any other public place;  Providing and receiving services;  In medical institutions;  In the common areas of educational institutions (both children aged 13 and over and teachers)."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113094112/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers    - A homemade mask should be made of at least three layers of suitable material (cotton, nylon, etc.) and have ties to secure it behind the ears or behind the head  - Wearing a face mask is not obligatory for children under 13 years of age or for people who have difficulty wearing a mask, for example, due to functional disorders  - Wearing a face mask is obligatory from the age of 13 outside the classroom at an educational establishment    https://web.archive.org/web/20201118093618/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

No new measures till 4th Nov 2020  Link - http://web.archive.org/web/20201107144025/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/binaries/rijksoverheid/documenten/publicaties/2020/11/03/coronavirus-factsheet-tijdelijke-verzwaring-van-de-gedeeltelijke-lockdown-vertalingen/201103_Maatr_3Nov_EN_02.pdf    Budget - http://web.archive.org/web/20201109113559/https://www.rijksfinancien.nl/overheidsfinancien-coronatijd/noodmaatregelen/uitgavenmaatregelen/noodmaatregelen-coronacrisis

From 10 PM on 4th Nov,  Groups  - Indoors and outdoors: max. 2 people or 1 household    Education  - In secondary and higher education face masks must be worn outside lessons    Venues normally open to the public  - Closure of museums, cinemas, theatres, zoos, swimming pools, libraries, sex establishments, amusement parks and other venues.    Food and drink / events  - Restaurants, bars and cafés remain closed.  - Takeaway restaurants can stay open. No alcohol may be sold or delivered after 20.00.  - Events are banned. Exceptions include funerals and demonstrations.    At Home  - Stay at home as much as possible.  - No more than 2 visitors per day (excluding children under 13).  - Follow the rules for selfquarantine and isolation.    Shops  - Shops close no later than 20.00. Except supermarkets, general markets and other stores that sell groceries.  - Ban on alcohol after 20.00. This applies to sales, deliveries and drinking alcohol in public spaces.    Transport  - Within the Netherlands: essential travel only.  - Do not travel abroad or book trips abroad. Travelling within the Kingdom is allowed.  - Wear a face mask on public transport.    Sport:   - no more than 2 people. Stay 1.5 metres apart. This does not apply to children under 18 and elite athletes  - No matches or competitions. With the exception of elite athletes.  - No spectators.  - Sports canteens, showers and changing rooms remain closed.  - No group lessons.     Link - http://web.archive.org/web/20201107144025/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/binaries/rijksoverheid/documenten/publicaties/2020/11/03/coronavirus-factsheet-tijdelijke-verzwaring-van-de-gedeeltelijke-lockdown-vertalingen/201103_Maatr_3Nov_EN_02.pdf    Budget - http://web.archive.org/web/20201109113559/https://www.rijksfinancien.nl/overheidsfinancien-coronatijd/noodmaatregelen/uitgavenmaatregelen/noodmaatregelen-coronacrisis

Main points:  - Restaurants closed, except take-away (until 1 am and no alcohol after 8 pm, hotels (no alcohol after 8 pm), funeral homes, company canteens   - Close-contact services are allowed with as much 1.5 distance as possible and masks 'urgently recommended'    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026155722/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-covid-19/ondernemers-en-bedrijven/horeca  https://web.archive.org/web/20201026160102/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-covid-19/openbaar-en-dagelijks-leven/contactberoepen

From 10 PM on 4th Nov,  Groups  - Indoors and outdoors: max. 2 people or 1 household    Education  - In secondary and higher education face masks must be worn outside lessons    Venues normally open to the public  - Closure of museums, cinemas, theatres, zoos, swimming pools, libraries, sex establishments, amusement parks and other venues.    Food and drink / events  - Restaurants, bars and cafés remain closed.  - Takeaway restaurants can stay open. No alcohol may be sold or delivered after 20.00.  - Events are banned. Exceptions include funerals and demonstrations.    At Home  - Stay at home as much as possible.  - No more than 2 visitors per day (excluding children under 13).  - Follow the rules for selfquarantine and isolation.    Shops  - Shops close no later than 20.00. Except supermarkets, general markets and other stores that sell groceries.  - Ban on alcohol after 20.00. This applies to sales, deliveries and drinking alcohol in public spaces.    Transport  - Within the Netherlands: essential travel only.  - Do not travel abroad or book trips abroad. Travelling within the Kingdom is allowed.  - Wear a face mask on public transport.    Sport:   - no more than 2 people. Stay 1.5 metres apart. This does not apply to children under 18 and elite athletes  - No matches or competitions. With the exception of elite athletes.  - No spectators.  - Sports canteens, showers and changing rooms remain closed.  - No group lessons.     Link - http://web.archive.org/web/20201107144025/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/binaries/rijksoverheid/documenten/publicaties/2020/11/03/coronavirus-factsheet-tijdelijke-verzwaring-van-de-gedeeltelijke-lockdown-vertalingen/201103_Maatr_3Nov_EN_02.pdf    Budget - http://web.archive.org/web/20201109113559/https://www.rijksfinancien.nl/overheidsfinancien-coronatijd/noodmaatregelen/uitgavenmaatregelen/noodmaatregelen-coronacrisis

Entry restrictions for most non-EU countries, with exceptions possible.     https://www.government.nl/topics/c/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/travel-and-holidays/visiting-the-netherlands (unable to archive the link)

An emergency law makes it possible to extend temporary rental contracts to avoid evictions during the corona crisis: https://web.archive.org/web/20201026194001/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/actueel/nieuws/2020/04/06/spoedwet-verlenging-tijdelijke-huurovereenkomsten-klaar    In addition, until 30 Dec 2020, lenders and borrowers can come to an agreement about a payment break for the payment of mortgages, but this is between the lending institution and the borrower, not govt policy: https://web.archive.org/web/20201026193751/https://www.belastingdienst.nl/wps/wcm/connect/nl/koopwoning/content/betaalpauze-hypotheekverplichtingen

On 30 Sept 2020, the Dutch govt for the first time recommended (but did not require) wearing masks in public spaces. Prior to this, masks had already been required in public transport. A medical mask is required when saying goodbye to an infected family member at home.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201026185328/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/actueel/nieuws/2020/09/30/dringend-advies-tot-dragen-van-mondkapjes

No change  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113151817/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-that-apply-to-everyone-from-5th-november/id2783881/
No change

Working from home is recommended. Distancing measures in place in offices.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201016180626/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/hjemmekontor-og-arbeidsplasser-covid-19
No change.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201016180626/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/hjemmekontor-og-arbeidsplasser-covid-19

On November 5th, the Government is adding several measures that municipalities in residential and working regions with high contagion pressure should consider introducing. One of them is mandatory home office.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113153042/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/stay-at-home-have-as-little-social-contact-as-possible/id2783763/
No change

Public events with up to 600 people are allowed outside as long as a distance of 2 meters can be kept. The group of 600 also needs to be devided into groups of 200 or less. Inside public events with up to 200 people are allowed. From October 28th new restrictions will be implemented.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/arrangementer-gruppestorrelse-og-avstand#arrangementer-pa-offentlig-sted-kan-gjennomfores-med-inntil-600-personer-utendors-og-200-personer-innendors

The number of participants attending private events held in public places or in leased or borrowed venues may not exceed a maximum of 50.  The current maximum of 600 attendees at outdoor events is limited to events where all attendees are seated in fixed seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201109235403/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/new-national-restrictions/id2776995/

There is a limit on private gatherings in public places and hired premises of 20 people, while the limit for indoor events without fixed seating is 50 people. The limit for indoor events where the full audience is seated in fixed seating remains 200 people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113153459/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/new-nationwide-measures/id2783806/
No change

https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/arrangementer-gruppestorrelse-og-avstand#private-sammenkomster-kan-gjennomfores-i-grupper-pa-maksimalt-20-personer  It is recommended that private events are limited to no more than 20 people including the people living in the house where the event takes place.   On October 26th it has been announced that from October 28th it is recommended that you as a private person do not invite more than 5 guest to your house.

The number of participants attending private events held in public places or in leased or borrowed venues may not exceed a maximum of 50.  The current maximum of 600 attendees at outdoor events is limited to events where all attendees are seated in fixed seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201109235403/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/new-national-restrictions/id2776995/

There is a limit on private gatherings in public places and hired premises of 20 people, while the limit for indoor events without fixed seating is 50 people. The limit for indoor events where the full audience is seated in fixed seating remains 200 people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113153459/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/new-nationwide-measures/id2783806/
No change

Public transportation is not closed but it is recommended to wear masks when using public transportation.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/reiser-reiseliv-og-kollektivtransport#kollektivselskapene-bor-iverksette-ekstra-rengjoring-av-tog-t-banevogner-bater-busser-og-trikker

The current advice is to avoid all unnecessary domestic travel. For public transport of shorter duration (e.g. under an hour) the general recommendation on keeping a distance of at least one metre can be deferred as long as the other measures are followed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201109235558/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/domestic-travels/
No change
No change
No change.

November 5th: The Government is introducing new national infection control measures.   “My message to the Norwegian people is: Stay at home as much as possible".  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113153042/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/stay-at-home-have-as-little-social-contact-as-possible/id2783763/
No change

No restrictions on internal movement as long as the general guidance of keeping distance and not travelling if you feel sick is followed.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/reiser-reiseliv-og-kollektivtransport#fritidsreiser

No change -no restrictions on internal movement as long as the general guidance of keeping distance and not travelling if you feel sick is followed.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/reiser-reiseliv-og-kollektivtransport#fritidsreiser

Avoid non-essential domestic travel. Work-related travel that is deemed essential and travel to and from second homes that can be completed without coming into contact with others are exempt.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113153459/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/new-nationwide-measures/id2783806/
No change

It is possible to get a test when entering to Norway from a foreign country. If you enter Norway from a red country you need to quarantine yourself.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/reiser-reiseliv-og-kollektivtransport#ankommende-fra-utlandet-far-mulighet-til-a-teste-seg-gratis-ved-ankomst

10-day quarantine upon arrival. A free Coronavirus testing service is available at many international airports in Norway. Taking a test at an airport is not mandatory and a negative result does not exempt you from quarantine or other recently introduced restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201110000111/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/norway/entry-requirements

No change: Persons who come to Norway must have a permanent residence in the country, or the employer or client must provide a guarantee of a suitable place of residence upon arrival in Norway. The following should be tested (further information about each point can be found in the collapsible box below):     Everyone with acute respiratory tract infection or other symptoms of COVID-19  Everyone who has been exposed to infection to COVID-19, either as a close contact or after travel to countries or regions with high incidence during the last 10 days*  Other groups can be tested after assessment by a doctor. If a person without symptoms and who has not been exposed is tested, a positive test must be confirmed with a new test.  Anyone who suspects that they have COVID-19 should have the opportunity to be tested  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/testing-and-follow-up/test-criteria-for-coronavirus/?term=&h=1
No change.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201110001515/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/testing-and-follow-up/test-criteria-for-coronavirus/?term=&h=1

The Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH/FHI) recommends that anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus is given the opportunity to be tested. Those that should get tested are:    Anyone showing symptoms of COVID-19, including anyone experiencing a sudden onset of symptoms of a respiratory tract infection.  Anyone who is a close contact to someone with confirmed COVID-19*.  Anyone arriving in Norway after having visited a red contry/area during the preceding 10-day period.  Anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus.  Other persons as assessed by a doctor.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113155943/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/testing-symptoms-and-close-contacts/
No change

Follow-up of close contacts, isolation and quarantine are measures to prevent transmission of the virus that causes COVID-19. Isolation and quarantine should be carried out in the most appropriate place, preferably at home. When the measures are introduced elsewhere than at home, the same principles apply.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/testing-and-follow-up/follow-up-close-contacts/?term=&h=1
https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/testing-and-follow-up/follow-up-close-contacts/?term=&h=1

If your test result comes back positive, you will be contacted by the local municipality and placed in isolation. The municipality will initiate contact tracing, and you will be asked to provide information on your close contacts during the preceding 48-hours period. The municipality will get in touch with your close contacts to inform them of their quarantine duty.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113155943/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/testing-symptoms-and-close-contacts/
No change

In situations with increased risk of transmission and where it is difficult to keep distance, face masks can be recommended as part of the measures to reduce the risk of transmission. Follow the local recommendations for the areas you are staying in.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/facts-and-general-advice/hand-hygiene-cough-etiquette-face-masks-cleaning-and-laundry/?term=&h=1

In areas with increased risk of transmission where the cases are not caused by known outbreaks or imported cases, face masks may be recommended where it is not possible to maintain a distance of 1 metre, for example on public transport. People can pass each other without a particular risk of transmission and the recommendations do not apply in these situations.     In areas with little or no known transmission, general recommendations to use face masks are not introduced (although people are free to use them).    The government has asked municipalities with local outbreaks to consider imposing face mask use indoors in public places (shops, malls) where it is not possible to maintain at least 1 metre distance, and indoors in restaurants for employees and for guests in all situations where they are not sitting at a table.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201110002538/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/facts-and-general-advice/munnbind-i-befolkningen/?term=&h=1

The following restrictions will come into effect on Saturday, October 24:     - The entire territory of Poland will become a 'red' zone;     - Restaurant activity will be limited for two weeks to serving only takeaway food;    - Grades four to eight in elementary schools will switch to remote learning;     - Secondary schools and higher learning institutions will switch to remote learning.    - Between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., children under the age of 16 will be allowed to leave their homes only in the company of an adult;    - Spectators will be banned from sporting events;    - There will be a 25-percent cap on audiences at all cultural events;    - Swimming pools, aquaparks and fitness clubs will be closed;    - Sanatoria will be closed;    - The number of people at retail premises of up to 100 square metres will be capped at five per checkout;     - The number of customers in retail premises above 100 square metres will be limited to one person per 15 square metres;    - Public transport will be limited to 50 percent of seating capacity or 30 percent of total capacity;    - Gatherings of more than five people will be banned, except for people living together in one home;    - Persons aged 70 and above are to encouraged to stay at home, apart from performing their professional activities, meeting their essential daily needs and participating in religious ceremonies.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201027185141/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

"The measures approved on October 14 remain in effect for the continental national territory:    . Raise the alert level to the situation of calamity;  . Gatherings are limited to 5 persons, in public spaces and in commercial establishments and services.  . Family events, such as baptisms and weddings, are limited to 50 persons.  . Prohibition of academic events such as parties, including reception practices for new students.  . Reinforcement of monitoring and inspection of compliance by the competent authorities.  . Increase of the maximum fine for non-compliance to € 10,000 (businesses).     In addition to these, the following remain in force:    . Prohibition of selling alcoholic beverages at service stations or at gas stations and at supermarkets and hypermarkets, after 20:00;  . Prohibition of selling alcoholic beverages in restaurants destined for consumption outside the establishment or for home delivery;  . Prohibition of the consumption of alcoholic beverages on public roads and outside spaces of restaurants and bars after 20:00, except in the context of meal service;  . Restriction of the maximum capacity in commercial establishments of 1 person per 13 square meters, to avoid concentration of people at the door;  . Restriction of the opening hours of commercial and service provision establishments, with the exception, for example, of pastry shops, cafés, hairdressers or gyms:        - opening hours only after 10:00;       - closing hours between 20:00 and 23:00;  These schedules may be adapted by the municipality with territorial authority, subject to a favorable opinion from the local health authority and the security forces.  . Recommendations of social distance and hands’ hygiene."    "Bars and Nightclubs remain closed and may operate only as cafes or pastries and are subject to the rules specified for these establishments."    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028110155/https://www.acm.gov.pt/-/covid-19-medidas-orientacoes-e-recomendacoes  http://web.archive.org/web/20201008030458/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/node/421189

121 Municipalities (mainly located in in the metropolitan areas of Lisbon and Porto) will be in partial confinement with new restrictions as at November 4.    IMPORTANT NEW RESTRICTIONS:    Required to remain at home (fica em casa), with the exception of essential travel to work, grocery stores, banks, pharmacies, care for the elderly, and exercise;  Mandatory telework where possible (already in force in Lisbon/Porto);  Social engagements (events/celebrations) limited to 5 people (unless from the same household);  Commercial establishments must close at 10 pm, except take-out, pharmacies, doctor’s offices, funeral homes, gas stations, and car rentals (local officials may adjust hours);  Restaurants must close at 10:30 pm, 6 people per group maximum, unless from the same household (local officials may adjust hours); and Markets and fairs must be approved by local government and operate according to DGS health guidelines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201105110407/https://pt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The F1 Grand Prix started on Friday, October 23 and end on Sunday, October 25, in Portimão (Algarve). The Grand Prix racing returned to Portugal for the first time in 24 years - the last time Formula 1 passed through Portugal was in 1996, in Estoril. Given the sanitary conditions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the AIA's capacity was of the Autódromo Internacional do Algarve (AIA) was reduced to 27,500 seats, according to the recommendations of the Directorate-General of Health (DGS).     "The images from the stands of the Formula 1 Grand Prix in Portugal are generating outrage, especially on social networks, due to the lack of distance between the public (...) some of the spectators were seen to breach the recommended social distance and without wearing face protection masks against Covid-19."    (Given that this event was only an exception and that all public events in the country are still cancelled this indicator was coded as 2G)    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201029163929/https://www.time24.news/2020/10/f1-in-portugal-the-images-that-are-generating-outrage-on-social-networks.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201029163726/https://observador.pt/2020/10/24/formula-1-quem-nao-cumprir-distanciamento-sera-expulso-do-autodromo-de-portimao/

The Council of Ministers approved stricter measures for three counties in the North region - Lousada, Felgueiras e Paços de Ferreira - that have registered a significant increase in the number of cases. The approved measures include: suspension of visits to care-homes, prohibition of events, duty to stay at home and mandatory teleworking. Rules take effect on Friday, October 23, at midnight.     Citizens should remain at home and refrain from circulating in public spaces and roads, except when the trips are authorized. Individuals are allowed to go out for grocery shopping, work (when teleworking is not possible), health reasons, to assist vulnerable people, attend school, physical activity in open spaces, cultural events, pet walk, among others. Air travel between Portugal and non-EU countries remains suspended. The following exceptions apply:    a)         Citizens of EU/Schengen/UK and their families, as well as residents of EU MS    b)        The UK and Schengen area countries (Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland)    c)         Essential travel from Lusophone countries: In the case of Brazil, only flights to and from Sao Paolo and Rio de Janeiro are permitted.    d)        Essential travel from the United States    e)         Third country nationals travelling for professional, study, family reunion, health or humanitarian reasons.    On basis of the European Council decision, travel is also permitted to and from the following locations: Australia, Canada, China, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia and Uruguay    https://web.archive.org/web/20201105114348/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/portugal/

Portugal's parliament on Friday passed a bill which imposed the mandatory use of a mask on the street and public spaces in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus.    The order was passed a day after authorities reported 3,270 new coronavirus cases, the highest single-day increase since the beginning of the pandemic. It will be in effect for at least 70 days.    The use of a mask is compulsory for all people "over ten years old to access, circulate or stay in public spaces and roads whenever the physical distance recommended by health authorities are impossible", according to the bill.    The obligation between "people from the same household, when they are not in the proximity of third parties" can be waived or by means of a "medical certificate" that the clinical condition or cognitive impairment does not allow the use of masks.    It is also not mandatory to wear a mask when "it is incompatible with the nature of the activities that people are carrying out."    Those who violate the order face fines of between 100 euros ($118) and 500 euros ($590). Other items such as visors will not be acceptable as substitutes.    The order will be reassessed following the expiry of the mandated period with a renewal a possibility."    These rules will be applied from Wednesday, October 28.     "The same rules will also be applied in Madeira and the Azores (...)"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028100351/https://newsaf.cgtn.com/news/2020-10-24/Portugal-s-Parliament-approves-mandatory-use-of-masks-in-outdoor-areas-UPMSI69oJy/index.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028100922/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2020-10-27-A-partir-de-quarta-feira-vai-ter-de-usar-mascara-na-rua

There are curfews in place from 21:00-05:00.  Persons over the age of 65 are only allowed to leave the house during the hours of 06:00-10:00 and 16:00-19:00.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201107200109/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

No change found.   - Persons over the age of 65 are only allowed to leave their place of residence between 6am and 10am and between 4pm and 7pm  - Division into high, medium and low risk municipalities.   High Risk Municipalities (Red): A curfew is in place between 7pm and 5am, during which time it is prohibited to be outside of your home except in an emergency and all businesses are closed.  Medium Risk Municipalities (Yellow): Places that sell food are prohibited from operating between 6pm and 5am, except for takeaways.  Low Risk Municipalities (Green): Places that sell food are prohibited from operating between 8pm and 5am, except for takeaways. "Bucharest closed its schools on Tuesday, switching to online learning for at least the next two weeks after the city recorded more than three cases of coronavirus per 1,000 residents over the previous two weeks."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022140108/https://www.euronews.com/2020/10/20/coronavirus-bucharest-schools-close-as-covid-19-surges-in-romania-s-capital

The Ministry of Education and Research announced on 22nd of October that 2401 education units are listed to work in red scenario (Scenario 3), involving the participation only in online activities. 4891 education units are listed in Scenario 2, meaning partial return (by rotation) in compliance with all rules of protection and 10364 in Scenario 1 (daily participation in compliance with all health protection rules).  According to the Order of the Minister of Education and Research and the Minister of Health 5487/1494/01.09.2020, one of the three operating scenarios is the cumulative incidence rate, respectively the total number of new cases in the last 14 days compared to 1000 inhabitants.  Links: https://archive.fo/EUjeg and https://archive.fo/qi24y

The Ministry of Education and Research announced on 26th of October that 3014 education units are listed to work in red scenario (Scenario 3), involving the participation only in online activities. 4894 education units are listed in Scenario 2, meaning partial return (by rotation) in compliance with all rules of protection and 9784 in Scenario 1 (daily participation in compliance with all health protection rules).  According to the Order of the Minister of Education and Research and the Minister of Health 5487/1494/01.09.2020, one of the three operating scenarios is the cumulative incidence rate, respectively the total number of new cases in the last 14 days compared to 1000 inhabitants.  Links: and https://archive.fo/qi24y

The Ministry of Education and Research announced on 30th of October that 3065 education units are listed to work in red scenario (Scenario 3), involving the participation only in online activities. 4938 education units are listed in Scenario 2, meaning partial return (by rotation) in compliance with all rules of protection and 9113 in Scenario 1 (daily participation in compliance with all health protection rules).  According to the Order of the Minister of Education and Research and the Minister of Health 5487/1494/01.09.2020, one of the three operating scenarios is the cumulative incidence rate, respectively the total number of new cases in the last 14 days compared to 1000 inhabitants.  Links: https://archive.fo/qi24y and https://archive.fo/qi24y
Many schools have moved to distance learning.  Link: https://archive.fo/kYCaw

According to the ministerial order 5972/8.11.20, starting with 9.11.20, the teaching activities that require the physical presence of preschoolers and students in preschool, primary, secondary, high school and post-secondary education units are suspended for a period of 30 days. The teaching activities will be carried out online, according to the Framework Methodology on conducting teaching activities through technology and the Internet, as well as for the processing of personal data, approved by order of the Ministry of Education and Research 5545/2020.  Links: https://archive.fo/7GMr0

"Bucharest closed its schools on Tuesday, switching to online learning for at least the next two weeks after the city recorded more than three cases of coronavirus per 1,000 residents over the previous two weeks.    That was the red line officials had given for imposing stricter measures, including closing all schools, indoor restaurants, cafes, theatres and cinemas for two weeks, and mandatory mask-wearing in all public spaces."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022140108/https://www.euronews.com/2020/10/20/coronavirus-bucharest-schools-close-as-covid-19-surges-in-romania-s-capital

Starting with 20th of October, the Bucharest City Committee for Emergency Situations announced that all activities carried out indoors in restaurants, coffee-shops, cinemas, theaters and gambling halls will be closed for at least 14 days, as disease rate of the city was over 3.  Also, the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection recommended on 10th of March measures to make labor relations more flexible (establishing individualized work programs, temporary modification of the workplace at the employee’s domicile, carrying out the activity through telework).  Link: https://archive.fo/mfaPX  and https://archive.fo/YIB63

The Government of Georgia imposed movement restrictions in major cities between 10 PM and 5 AM. During the restricted time, public and private transportation (including walking) is not permitted, unless it is for an essential need.  Link: https://archive.fo/kYCaw

The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities. Also, the Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Also, GEO 30/2020 refers to the measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.      Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/FtT0q.

"Bucharest closed its schools on Tuesday, switching to online learning for at least the next two weeks after the city recorded more than three cases of coronavirus per 1,000 residents over the previous two weeks.    That was the red line officials had given for imposing stricter measures, including closing all schools, indoor restaurants, cafes, theatres and cinemas for two weeks, and mandatory mask-wearing in all public spaces."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022140108/https://www.euronews.com/2020/10/20/coronavirus-bucharest-schools-close-as-covid-19-surges-in-romania-s-capital

The Minister of Health, Nelu Tataru, announced on 22nd of May the obligation to wear a protective mask, epidemiological triage and mandatory hand disinfection to prevent contamination with SARS CoV-2 virus during the alert state. According to the Government Decision 394/2020, from 15th of October 2020, the alert status will be extended by 30 days. Moreover, starting with 20th of October, the Bucharest City Committee for Emergency Situations announced that the protective mask must be worn both indoors and outdoors, as disease rate was over 3. The key measures approved by the government include: minimum guaranteed income for poorer households (so, it appears to apply for everyone - in both formal and informal sectors).   Euro 580 wages per family that increases based on number of family members(See second article)  http://web.archive.org/web/20201101203718/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20201101205846/https://www.euronews.com/2020/04/25/can-san-marino-s-aggressive-covid-19-testing-strategy-save-europe

The key measures approved by the government include: i) suspension of payment deadlines for government tax and non-tax obligations, utility bills, and other dues to provide liquidity to the private sector; ii) temporary freeze of all non-essential government spending and reduction in public sector wage bill to redirect spending to the health sector; and iii) extension of supplemental wage scheme to support workers displaced by COVID-19 containment measures; iv) deferral of income tax payment; v)minimum guaranteed income for poorer households; vi) other measures to support businesses, including tax credits, tax payments postponement and rescheduling; vii) an economic recovery fund, financed initially through a temporary solidarity levy applied on pensions (above 1500 euros). Measures related to social protection will remain in place until December 2020, subject to reassessment every two months.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201101203718/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
